# BEGIN: Fair Trades (Ares' arc)
The Narrator (dejapes) BOT 11-11-2024 21:13
(For Ares) Like the oppressive rhythm of a grandfather clock, the malady in your throat is a constant reminder of the passage of time. It draws out the hours, robs you of your sleep, and interrupts hard-earned moments of peace. In recent days, it has grown worse. Whether manifesting itself in an itch that seems to layer itself beneath your skin, or a coughing fit that almost leaves you in dry heaves, the ailment continues to make itself worse. It stubbornly resists all curatives, whether mundane or magical, and no healer or apothecary in Barovia's admittedly limited and fearful population can even discern its source. There is, however, one person who is rumored to have uncanny talents in the matters of flesh. Some speak of him as a holy man who resurrected the decaying Abbey of Saint Markovia. Others whisper of a madman who has yet to age a day since he appeared, and who keeps in his company twisted mongrelfolk. Perhaps in his madness lies insight. Either way, your options grow fewer.
The Narrator (dejapes) BOT 11-11-2024 21:14
- (For Everyone) The village of Krezk is insular, its gates shut to the outside world more often than they are open. Within that fearful, isolated town stands a grand Abbey dedicated to Saint Markovia, its battlements and monuments of faith preserved in slow decay. It is said that a holy man appeared one day and saved the Abbey from utter ruination. It is also said that he is reclusive, erratic to the point of madness, and difficult to reach. All of which makes this job posting all the more unusual. On the pitted surface of a public board in Krezk, sparsely populated by long-expired advertisements and faded descriptions of those who have gone missing, a page of crisp vellum paper stands out. Penned with exactingly perfect calligraphy, the posting declares the following:
The Abbot seeks daring and reliable sellswords to represent the Abbey in a matter urgent and essential.  Interested parties are invited to enjoy the hospitality of the faithful of Saint Markovia during the midday hour of the ninth day of Neyavr.
Whatever your reasons, you find yourselves before the abbey gates as noon approaches. It is far from a good day; what passes for daylight in Barovia has been completely blotted out by clouds the color of dull ochre, and flecks of crimson snow drift from a cursed sky. The abbey stands above the walled town, atop a hill. Behind you, Krezk sprawls out modestly, dotted by stone chimneys and pigsties. Before you, the abbey's gates remain closed. But soon, perhaps, they will not be.

Georg BOT 11-11-2024 21:35
*Outside the abbey gates, a dark-haired man who is armed to the teeth is pacing back and forth. On his back is a beautiful longbow -- light yew wood body covered in dragon scales -- and from his shoulders flow a long crimson cloak, upon which a small emblem of Tyr, a set of balances standing atop an upright hammer, is embroidered. He is clad in a scale-mail seemingly made of dragon scales sewn together, and the source of all that dragon scale becomes abundantly clear. As he paces nervously, he is shielded from the incessant bloody snowflakes by the extended wing of a patient, large white drake, who stands statuesque by the ranger, offering him shelter but remaining motionless save for the eyes that track the man's erratic footsteps.* "Maybe... just maybe... if I do this favor for him... he will reconsider my plea." He mutters, unclear whether to himself or to the drake. (edited)

Enter Ares _Ares walks quietly up the main street of Krezk toward the gate. She wears a worn, heavy, hooded cloak over her gear. Only a large blade tinted purple, blue, and yellow from constant exposure to high heat, strapped across her back visually identifies her as anyone of note._ _She's been unusually quiet, recently, even for her. Ever since they made it back from the temple, she's been withdrawn - rarely leaving their room, buying an amulet to hide her location, pretty much not even speaking unless spoken to, and even then..._ _But the attacks are getting worse and worse, and it isn't just the cold. Carnaxa has, more than once, had to hold her hair back as she leans over a bucket of coagulated blood, gasping for breath. Her options now are... less than plentiful. Ares doesn't know who she would turn to at this point if she were still back home. Here, there is at least one. She's heard word of an Abbot. Some good, some bad. All of it seems to paint him as someone with... some amount of healing capability. So she'll take what she can get._ _She raises her head at the man standing by the gate. He looks... somewhat familiar. Vaguely. Definitely can't remember his name._ "Still closed?" _She calls out to him, punctuated by a few coughs._

The Narrator (dejapes) BOT 13-11-2024 04:54
The gate opens with a wooden groan, grinding through ice. The courtyard beyond, partially sheltered by a surrounding curtain wall, is nestled between the two wings of the abbey. Red snow layers building and battlement alike, but one can still make out stone sheds with padlocked doors, as well as frost-covered troughs. A path has been kept clear for visitors - you, presumably. It leads east towards one of the wings, a stately edifice with arched arched windows. Lights glimmer beyond the leaded glass, hinting at dry warmth. There are two figures in the courtyard, both heavily obscured by hooded cloaks and winter coats. The one that opened the gate hovers in the shadows near it, head tucked in as if not wanting to meet your eyes. The other stands by the well with a broom, sweeping red snow off the path. The one with the broom bows their hooded head and speaks. Their voice grumbles and hisses like a cross between a hound and a rat, but their tone affects politeness. "The Abbot awaits you in the main hall, please join him." Their hand sweeps towards the eastern wing, where the main door is slightly ajar. A long sleeve droops over their hand, but can't quite hide a finger, strangely shaped with mottled scales.

The Narrator (dejapes) BOT 13-11-2024 20:09
The east wing's door opens on approach, warmth flooding over the visitors as they step in from the blood snow. The main hall is a dining hall, with more chairs than is needed. The abbey's many windows, squirreled away rooms, and suggested dimensions suggest that the place used to be the home of scores of faithful. But thus far you have seen only a couple of misshapen figures in the deep shadows of hooded robes, and now the Abbot. The man stands, stately, in humble linen vestments that are clean and crisp to the point that they seem to shine with a pearly luminescence. He has an undeniable presence.

The Abbot (dejapes) BOT 13-11-2024 20:09
The abbot has his back turned when the door opens. His attention seems to be directed towards an empty expanse of floor, seemingly reserved for a dancer's practice. A woman glides across the old, polished wood paneling. Her dress rustles over the floor as she takes to the routine with silent, mechanical grace. The abbot is clapping steadily to count rhythm. One, two, three, one- But when the door opens, he stops and tilts his head ever so slightly. He speaks in a gentle, patient tone. "That is enough, Vasilka. Let us greet our guests." He turns, bringing palms together in saintly benediction. The warmth of his smile is radiant. "Welcome to the Abbey of St. Markovia, and thank you for the prompt response to my missive. Please, have a seat." Behind him, the woman - dressed in a sable dress with a veil that obscures her face - dips into a curtsey. (edited)

She pours a cup of tea before each occupied guest chair, each time controlling the pour with the delicate presence of an index and middle finger atop the pot. Her movements are graceful, but graceful in the same way a clockwork toy is graceful. The veiled woman serves each cup similarly, with the same mechanical politeness.

The Narrator (dejapes) BOT 19-11-2024 08:27
- By the witch's estimation, there are two options for intercepting the noble. The first is to travel by (relatively) safe roads to Vallaki, then take the southern paths towards the Andrejco estate. The groups will likely meet each other on the road, perhaps in fields near the ruined windmill known to the locals as the Old Bonegrinder. The terrain is open and ambush will be difficult, making a direct confrontation likely. The second is to take a riskier, direct path through the Svalich. This will involve scouting and wilderness navigation to avoid becoming lost in the misty woods. But if successful, there is a chance at catching the noble at night in camp in the wilds, which may be a more advantageous encounter. But if the group gets lost in the woods, or fails to find the noble's camp, they might miss the window of interception entirely. There is also the matter of the Abbot's agent and his carriage. If the party were to choose to pass through Vallaki first, it would be possible to leave him to wait in town. The assumption would be that he would be safe behind Vallaki's walls. Given the intrigue surrounding the auction, that may not be a safe assumption.

DM [Ricochet] BOT 25-11-2024 03:23
One by one, each of the mercenary party devises a means of forgoing the comfort and relative warmth of the wagon for some other, more stylish transportation. Yves makes no comment and simply climbs onto the driver's seat of the carriage, flicking the reins lightly to urge the team forward. Two small, hunched figures in heavy cloaks drag the gate open through the freshly fallen snow once more. A single, unnaturally large yellow eye peers at them from the depths of one hood as they pass. The horses make a slow pace down the mountain Abbey and through Krezk, earning stares from cracked doors and shuttered windows, but the team picks up some speed once they are out of the city gates. Still, the day and a half seems like a good estimate for the carriage's travel to Vallaki. The mares are mundane animals after all, and even with an empty carriage, they are still pulling it through mud and snow. If the party pushed the horses, they could perhaps make it to Vallaki early the next morning, but one night camping on the road seems inevitable without further intervention. Travel on the road passes without great incident as Georg and Carnaxa in the sky help the team avoid or dispatch wandering werewolves and other starved animals who dare seek them out.

The Narrator (dejapes) BOT 16-01-2025 08:58
The device is structurally simple and the arcane runes carved into the wooden box describe no great magic. They are simple abjuration wards, proofing it against the elements and reinforcing it against hard impacts and sudden shocks. The most intricate rune is an illusory effect, which made the metal-banded box resemble the other iron cages on the back of the cart. This illusion is a temporary one, the rune set to expire in a day or two. And yet Yves described this as a cage for unknowable horrors. Outwardly, it was just a box with mirrors. However, the witch had encountered some of the more esoteric knowledge regarding mirrored surfaces. There were stories from different lands that implied a connection between a reflection and the soul. Ghosts were known to dwell behind the glass, and vampires were rumored be revealed by their absence in the mirrored realm. For the most part such notions were superstitions, folklore. Still, with those tales in mind, Carnaxa began to note the oddities among the mirrors. They were not uniform; their tints and hues suggested subtly colored glass, or more exotic material. Some were slightly warped, others were shaped into a curious asymmetry. And then she senses it. Some traditions maintain that a reflection is but a fragment, a sliver. A mirror can only see so much. But an array of mirrors is dangerously puissant, and under the right angle the entirety of the soul can be affixed in place. For a fleeting moment, an unfamiliar reflection looks back at Carnaxa. It is fragmented, its rage and terror spliced between multiple mirrored realms. Its unmitigated hatred is diffused into passing glimmers. The witch draws two conclusions. On a practical level, the array does not rely on extradimensional space; it would be safe to carry it in a portable hole. Second, it is not empty. Something is already trapped within.

The Narrator (dejapes) BOT 10-02-2025 21:43
The story told was likely a familiar one to a ranger trekking across the countryside. Smaller, poorer farming families often had difficulty working their own land. To survive the year they needed draft animals and metal tools, valuable capital possessed usually by local lords or much larger estates. These 'big men' received the less well-off families and doled out resources in exchange for favors, taxes, or other kinds of political support. These relations ranged from abusive and oppressive to the more benign. The way these two women spoke, their relationship with the Andreides leaned towards the latter. They were hoping the elder Andreides would consent to them retaining a borrowed bull and a plow for the planting season, and had brought with them a small basket of dried fruit in exchange. Georg might not have been a farmer himself, but this seemed to be a rather nominal fee - more of a gift in appreciation of generosity.. The women had little else to offer in terms of information, but the older one did offer a tidbit. She had brought with her a small bundle of flowers. Tomas Andreides was wont to lay a wreath on the gravestone of his daughter in the town cemetary, and the anniversary of her death was the day after tomorrow.

The Narrator (dejapes) BOT 13-02-2025 05:09
The scent is a familiar one to the witch. There is a breed of nightshade common to the Svalich Woods, one used for both medicines and poisons. What is unusual, however, is the purity of the sample and certain mineral traces. This was no amateur midwife brewing a malady in a teapot. Rather, this is a potent poison that likely required complex distillation and a specialized alchemical assembly. If the victim was a normal adult man, the poison would have likely stopped the heart within minutes of entering a blood vessel. The residue is already breaking up and losing potency from exposure to air. The Narrator (dejapes) BOT 20-02-2025 22:27
On a lonely road north of Vallaki, the party briefly encamped to eat before the journey ahead, Georg reaches for the mirror array. The device is a set of mirrors, each of a different material, all pointed inwards and held in place by frame of brass. The mirrors catch each other's reflections, so that each bear a fragmented composite of the frigid outside world. Saoirse's inked magic is as reliable as ever, but drawing a ritual from the tattoo does still require the basic formulation of the spell. In this case, arcane identification requires touching an object for a full minute, and Georg's hand comes to rest directly on a mirror. For ten seconds, then twenty, little happens. The tattoo on Georg's flesh twinkles with life, and he can feel the tingle of its magic being drawn out. Then he hears a whisper like a shivering exhale. The tongue is unfamiliar; indeed, it does not sound like it could have been produced by a tongue at all. Nonetheless, he can make out distinct words, and exceedingly beautiful ones at that. Allured by their diction, Georg sinks into a trance. The realm of Barovia fades from Georg's eyes, as does his memories of journeying the misty land. He sits in camp, not alongside a wintry lake, but beneath the autumnal canopy of the Skyraker Forest. His bandaged body is garbed in the tattered uniform of a Brelish scout, and he is fleeing a war - but not the war as he knew it. Sharn splinters from creeping carapace, and unspeakable things claw their way free from the earth. Hope is lost; he and Lyon must escape across the sea. Even now, his beloved sleeps in a bedroll across the embers of a firepit. But to Georg's alarm, he sees the ground shift. The Enemy is burrowing out of the ground beside his precious partner. Limbs, many-jointed and armored, burst from soil and embrace the slumbering soldier. Georg knows what he must do. He must take up arms and hack it and crush it until he and his loved one are safe.

Through the cold mist, one can make out the sharp lines and angles of rooftops. A hamlet of that size should, in the dead of winter, show signs of life - a column of chimney smoke here or there, or the far glow of a lantern or a hearth. It is quiet and dead.

Frozen crops, withered and dry and abandoned, litter the gardens. There is one building that looks to be relatively intact, its windows boarded but with the suggestion of light glimmering through the cracks. It looms over the town from atop a modest hill; you can infer from the belltower and the steepled roof that it used to be a chapel. There is a direct path to it, one that winds through a dirt yard that could have once been the village center. A lonely well stands at the center. It is there that you discover that you are not alone. Four snow-covered figures surrounding the square shift subtly.
